data.title: Pulitzer Prize
data.meta_description: This page lists the Pulitzer prize winners to date. The Pulitzer prize is an award for achievements in, inter alia>, newspaper, magazine and literature in the United States. This prize system has been in place since 1917 and is funded by the will of Joseph Pulitzer (an American who made a fortune by publishing newspapers).â€¦
data.text:
â® Poetry & Prose â® Books / People

The Pulitzer Prize is an award for achievements in, inter alia, newspaper, magazine and literature in the United States. This prize system has been in place since 1917 and is funded by the will of Joseph Pulitzer (an American who made a fortune by publishing newspapers). At present the annual prizes are decided upon and granted by Columbia University, New York City.

Investigative Reporting

1950s

1953: Edward J. Mowery, New York World-Telegram & Sun, â€œfor his reporting of the facts which brought vindication and freedom to Louis Hoffner.â€

1954: Alvin McCoy, The Kansas City Star, â€œfor a series of exclusive stories which led to the resignation under fire of C. Wesley Roberts as Republican National Chairman.â€

1955: Roland Kenneth Towery, Cuero Record (Texas), â€œfor his series of articles exclusively exposing a scandal in the administration of the Veteransâ€™ Land Program in Texas. This 32-year-old World War II veteran, a former prisoner of the Japanese, made these irregularities a state-wide and subsequently a national issue, and stimulated state action to rectify conditions in the land program.â€

1956: Arthur Daley, The New York Times, â€œfor his outstanding coverage and commentary on the world of sports in his daily column, Sports of the Times.â€

1957: Wallace Turner and William Lambert, Portland Oregonian, â€œfor their expose of vice and corruption in Portland involving some municipal officials and officers of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America, Western Conference. They fulfilled their assignments despite great handicaps and the risk of reprisal from lawless elements.â€

1958: George Beveridge, Evening Star (Washington, D.C.), â€œfor his excellent and thought-provoking series, â€œMetro, City of Tomorrow,â€ describing in depth the urban problems of Washington, D.C., which stimulated widespread public consideration of these problems and encouraged further studies by both public and private agencies.â€

1959: John Harold Brislin, Scranton Tribune and Scrantonian, â€œfor displaying courage, initiative and resourcefulness in his effective four-year campaign to halt labor violence in his home city, as a result of which ten corrupt union officials were sent to jail and a local union was embolden to clean out racketeering elements.â€

1960: Miriam Ottenberg, Evening Star (Washington, D.C.), â€œfor a series of seven articles exposing a used-car racket in Washington, D.C., that victimized many unwary buyers. The series led to new regulations to protect the public and served to alert other communities to such sharp practices.â€

1961: Edgar May, Buffalo Evening News, â€œfor his series of articles on New York Stateâ€™s public welfare services entitled, Our Costly Dilemma, based in part on his three-month employment as a state case worker. The series brought about reforms that attracted nationwide attention.â€

1962: George Bliss, Chicago Tribune, â€œfor his initiative in uncovering scandals in the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago, with resultant remedial action.â€

1963: Oscar Griffin Jr., Pecos Independent and Enterprise, â€œwho as editor initiated the exposure of the Billie Sol Estes scandal and thereby brought a major fraud on the United States government to national attention with resultant investigation, prosecution and conviction of Estes.â€

Pulitzer Prize for Local Investigative Specialized Reporting[edit]

1964: James V. Magee, Albert V. Gaudiosi and Frederick Meyer, Philadelphia Bulletin, â€œfor their expose of numbers racket operations with police collusion in South Philadelphia, which resulted in arrests and a cleanup of the police department.â€

1965: Gene Goltz, Houston Post, â€œfor his expose of government corruption Pasadena, Texas, which resulted in widespread reforms.â€

1966: John Anthony Frasca, Tampa Tribune, â€œfor his investigation and reporting of two robberies that resulted in the freeing of an innocent man.â€

1967: Gene Miller, Miami Herald, â€œfor initiative and investigative reporting that helped to free two persons wrongfully convicted of murder.â€

1968: J. Anthony Lukas, The New York Times, â€œfor the social document he wrote in his investigation of the life and the murder of Linda Fitzpatrick.â€

1969: Al Delugach and Denny Walsh, St. Louis Globe-Democrat, â€œfor their campaign against fraud and abuse of power within the St. Louis Steamfitters Union, Local 562.â€

1970: Harold Eugene Martin, Montgomery Advertiser and Alabama Journal, â€œfor his expose of a commercial scheme for using Alabama prisoners for drug experimentation and obtaining blood plasma from them.â€

1971: William Jones, Chicago Tribune, â€œfor exposing collusion between police and some of Chicagoâ€™s largest private ambulance companies to restrict service in low income areas, leading to major reforms.â€

1972: Timothy Leland, Gerard M. Oâ€™Neill, Stephen A. Kurkjian and Ann Desantis, Boston Globe, â€œfor their exposure of widespread corruption in Somerville, Massachusetts.â€

1973: The Sun Newspapers Of Omaha, â€œfor uncovering the large financial resources of Boys Town, Nebraska, leading to reforms in this charitable organizationâ€™s solicitation and use of funds contributed by the public.â€

1974: William Sherman, New York Daily News, â€œfor his resourceful investigative reporting in the exposure of extreme abuse of the New York Medicaid program.â€

1975: Indianapolis Star, â€œfor its disclosures of local police corruption and dilatory law enforcement, resulting in a cleanup of both the Police Department and the office of the County Prosecutor.â€

1976: Staff of Chicago Tribune, â€œfor uncovering widespread abuses in Federal housing programs in Chicago and exposing shocking conditions at two private Chicago hospitals.â€

1977: Acel Moore and Wendell Rawls Jr., The Philadelphia Inquirer, â€œfor their reports on conditions in the Farview (Pa.) State Hospital for the mentally ill.â€

1978: Anthony R. Dolan, Stamford Advocate, â€œfor a series on municipal corruption.â€

1979: Gilbert M. Gaul and Elliot G. Jaspin, Pottsville Republican (Pennsylvania), â€œfor stories on the destruction of the Blue Coal Company by men with ties to organized crime.â€

1980: Stephen A. Kurkjian, Alexander B. Hawes Jr., Nils Bruzelius, Joan Vennochi and Robert M. Porterfield, Boston Globe, â€œfor articles on Bostonâ€™s transit system.â€

1981: Clark Hallas and Robert B. Lowe, Arizona Daily Star, â€œfor their investigation of the University of Arizona Athletic Department.â€

1982: Paul Henderson, Seattle Times, â€œfor reporting which proved the innocence of a man convicted of rape.â€

1983: Loretta Tofani, The Washington Post, â€œfor her investigation of rape and sexual assault in the Prince Georgeâ€™s County, Maryland Detention Center.â€

1984: Kenneth Cooper, Joan Fitz Gerald, Jonathan Kaufman, Norman Lockman, Gary McMillan, Kirk Scharfenberg and David Wessel, Boston Globe, â€œfor their series examining race relations in Boston, a notable exercise in public service that turned a searching gaze on some the cityâ€™s most honored institutions including the Globe itself.â€

Pulitzer Prize for Investigative Reporting[edit]

1985: Lucy Morgan and Jack Reed, St. Petersburg Times (Florida), â€œfor their thorough reporting on Pasco County Sheriff John Short, which revealed his departmentâ€™s corruption and led to his removal from office by voters.â€

1985: William K. Marimow, The Philadelphia Inquirer, â€œfor his revelation that city police dogs had attacked more than 350 people â€“ an exposure that led to investigations of the K-9 unit and the removal of a dozen officers from it.â€

1986: Jeffrey A. Marx and Michael M. York, Lexington Herald-Leader (Kentucky), â€œfor their series â€˜Playing Above the Rules,â€™ which exposed cash payoffs to University of Kentucky basketball players in violation of NCAA regulations. However, the UK basketball program did little to reform itself in the wake of the articles; true reform would not come until the program was involved in another cash-for-recruits scandal three years later.â€

1987: Daniel R. Biddle, H.G. Bissinger, and Fredric N. Tulsky, The Philadelphia Inquirer, â€œfor their series â€˜Disorder in the Court,â€™ which revealed transgressions of justice in the Philadelphia court system and led to federal and state investigations.â€

1988: Dean Baquet, William C. Gaines, and Ann Marie Lipinski, Chicago Tribune, â€œfor their detailed reporting on the self-interest and waste that plague Chicagoâ€™s City Council.â€

1989: Bill Dedman, Atlanta Journal and Constitution, â€œfor his investigation of the racial discrimination practiced by lending institutions in Atlanta, reporting which led to significant reforms in those policies.â€

1990: Lou Kilzer and Chris Ison, Minneapolis-St. Paul Star Tribune, â€œfor reporting that exposed a network of local citizens who had links to members of the St. Paul fire department and who profited from fires, including some described by the fire department itself as being of suspicious origin.â€

1991: Joseph T. Hallinan and Susan M. Headden, The Indianapolis Star, â€œfor their shocking series on medical malpractice in the state.â€

1992: Lorraine Adams and Dan Malone, The Dallas Morning News, â€œfor reporting that charged Texas police with extensive misconduct and abuses of power.â€

1993: Jeff Brazil and Steve Berry, Orlando Sentinel (Florida), â€œfor exposing the unjust seizure of millions of dollars from motorists â€“ most of them minorities â€“ by a sheriffâ€™s drug squad.â€

1994: Providence Journal-Bulletin (Rhode Island) staff, â€œfor thorough reporting that disclosed pervasive corruption within the Rhode Island court system.â€

1995: Stephanie Saul and Brian Donovan, Newsday, â€œfor their stories that revealed disability pension abuses by local police.â€

1996: The Orange County Register staff, â€œfor reporting that uncovered fraudulent and unethical fertility practices at a leading research university hospital and prompted key regulatory reforms.â€

1997: Eric Nalder, Deborah Nelson, and Alex Tizon, The Seattle Times, for their investigation of widespread corruption and inequities in the federally sponsored housing program for Native Americans, which inspired much-needed reforms.

1998: Gary Cohn and Will Englund, The Baltimore Sun, â€œfor their compelling series on the international shipbreaking industry that revealed the dangers posed to workers and the environment when discarded ships are dismantled.â€

1999: The Miami Herald staff, â€œfor its detailed reporting that revealed pervasive voter fraud in a city mayoral election that was subsequently overturned.â€

2010s

2000: Sang-Hun Choe, Charles J. Hanley, and Martha Mendoza, Associated Press, â€œfor a report on the killings of Korean civilians by American soldiers in the early days of the Korean War.â€

2001: David Willman, Los Angeles Times, â€œfor his pioneering exposÃ© of seven unsafe prescription drugs that had been approved by the Food and Drug Administration, and an analysis of the policy reforms that had reduced the agencyâ€™s effectiveness.â€

2002: Sari Horwitz, Scott Higham, and Sarah Cohen, The Washington Post, â€œfor a series that exposed the District of Columbiaâ€™s role in the neglect and death of 229 children placed in protective care between 1993 and 2000, which prompted an overhaul of the cityâ€™s child welfare system.â€

2003: Clifford J. Levy, The New York Times, â€œfor his vivid, brilliantly written series â€˜Broken Homesâ€™ that exposed the abuse of mentally ill adults in state-regulated homes.â€

2004: Michael D. Sallah, Joe Mahr, and Mitch Weiss, Toledo Blade, â€œfor a series on atrocities by the Tiger Force during the Vietnam War.â€

2005: Nigel Jaquiss of Willamette Week, Portland, Oregon, â€œfor his investigation exposing former governor Neil Goldschmidtâ€˜s long concealed sexual misconduct with a 14-year-old girl.â€

2006: Susan Schmidt, James V. Grimaldi and R. Jeffrey Smith of The Washington Post, â€œfor their indefatigable probe of Washington lobbyist Jack Abramoff that exposed congressional corruption and produced reform efforts.â€

2007: Brett Blackledge of The Birmingham News, â€œfor his exposure of cronyism and corruption in the stateâ€™s two-year college system, resulting in the dismissal of the chancellor and other corrective action.â€

2008: (Two winning newspapers) Walt Bogdanich and Jake Hooker of The New York Times, â€œfor their stories on toxic ingredients in medicine and other everyday products imported from China, leading to crackdowns by American and Chinese officials.â€ Staff of The Chicago Tribune, â€œfor its exposure of faulty governmental regulation of toys, car seats and cribs, resulting in the extensive recall of hazardous products and congressional action to tighten supervision.â€

2009: David Barstow of The New York Times, for his tenacious reporting that revealed how some retired generals, working as radio and television analysts, had been co-opted by the Pentagon to make its case for the war in Iraq, and how many of them also had undisclosed ties to companies that benefited from policies they defended.â€

2010s

2010: Barbara Laker and Wendy Ruderman of the Philadelphia Daily News and Sheri Fink of ProPublica, in collaboration with The New York Times Magazine. Laker and Ruderman won for â€œtheir resourceful reporting that exposed a rogue police narcotics squad, resulting in an FBI probe and the review of hundreds of criminal cases tainted by the scandalâ€, Fink for â€œa story that chronicles the urgent life-and-death decisions made by one hospitalâ€™s exhausted doctors when they were cut off by the floodwaters of Hurricane Katrina.â€

2011: Paige St. John of the Sarasota Herald-Tribune, â€œfor her examination of weaknesses in the murky property-insurance system vital to Florida homeowners, providing handy data to assess insurer reliability and stirring regulatory action.â€

2012: (Two winning newspapers) Matt Apuzzo, Adam Goldman, Eileen Sullivan and Chris Hawley of the Associated Press, â€œfor their spotlighting of the New York Police Departmentâ€™s clandestine spying program that monitored daily life in Muslim communities, resulting in congressional calls for a federal investigation, and a debate over the proper role of domestic intelligence gathering,â€ and Michael J. Berens and Ken Armstrong of The Seattle Times, â€œfor their investigation of how a little known governmental body in Washington State moved vulnerable patients from safer pain-control medication to methadone, a cheaper but more dangerous drug, coverage that prompted statewide health warnings.â€

2013: David Barstow and Alejandra Xanic von Bertrab The New York Times, â€œfor their reports on how Wal-Mart used widespread bribery to dominate the market in Mexico, resulting in changes in company practices.â€

2014: Chris Hamby of The Center for Public Integrity, Washington, D.C. â€œfor his reports on how some lawyers and doctors rigged a system to deny benefits to coal miners stricken with black lung disease, resulting in remedial legislative efforts.â€[3]

2015: (Two winners) Eric Lipton of The New York Times â€œfor reporting that showed how the influence of lobbyists can sway congressional leaders and state attorneys general, slanting justice toward the wealthy and connectedâ€ and The Wall Street Journal staff â€œfor â€˜Medicare Unmasked,â€™ a pioneering project that gave Americans unprecedented access to previously confidential data on the motivations and practices of their health care providers.â€[4] The Wall Street Journal team included John Carreyrou, Chris Stewart, Rob Barry, Tom McGinty, Martin Burch, Jon Keegan and Stuart Thompson.[5]

2016: Leonora LaPeter Anton and Anthony Cormier of the Tampa Bay Times and Michael Braga of the Sarasota Herald-Tribune â€œfor a stellar example of collaborative reporting by two news organizations that revealed escalating violence and neglect in Florida mental hospitals and laid the blame at the door of state officials.â€

2017

Eric Eyre of Charleston Gazette-Mail, Charleston, West Virginia â€œfor courageous reporting, performed in the face of powerful opposition, to expose the flood of opioids flowing into depressed West Virginia counties with the highest overdose death rates in the country.â€[6]

2018:

The staff of The Washington Post â€œfor purposeful and relentless reporting that changed the course of a Senate race in Alabama by revealing a candidateâ€™s alleged past sexual harassment of teenage girls and subsequent efforts to undermine the journalism that exposed it.â€

2019

Matt Hamilton, Harriet Ryan and Paul Pringle of the Los Angeles Times â€œfor consequential reporting on a University of Southern California gynecologist accused of violating hundreds of young women for more than a quarter-century.â€
